The best part about canvas is you can make your views REALLY flat
You don't need to create nested view groups to achieve certain border and background affects. You just paint that shit underneath.

<@U07DEGHHT|nickpontiff> uploaded a file: <https://androidchat.slack.com/files/nickpontiff/F0AN2M1L4/slack_for_ios_upload.png|Slack for iOS Upload> and commented: So this is an overdraw comparison of our post list at GotChosen before and after, along with FB, Google + and IG. Each post is divided into sections and they are all their own list item. Header, title, body, vote row etc. Each section is just 1 relative layout with the only child views being for actual content. This is a custom drawable used to paint the necessary background pieces and borders. <https://gist.github.com/NickPontiff/c35fcdfd0aa9503c2105>

initial_comment.comment: So this is an overdraw comparison of our post list at GotChosen before and after, along with FB, Google + and IG. nah they can try to optimize things but you still have core issues there
I have a question about talking to JSON APIs
I have two very similar returned objects. Would you still create two POJOs for them, or can gson handle things like "one different param name"?
compare this: <https://chain.so/api/v2/get_address_balance/DOGE/DFundmtrigzA6E25Swr2pRe4Eb79bGP8G1> to <https://chain.so/api/v2/get_address_received/DOGE/DFundmtrigzA6E25Swr2pRe4Eb79bGP8G1>
unrelated: I _hate_ apis that return "status": success
me too
we know. that's what the 200 status code was for.
if you want pojo mapping i wouldn’t do it like that
as for status that should be the http code
use a typeadapter to dump that shit
<@U060Q7J2Y>: so true
well, it is the http code too :wink:
use two different models for the stuff inside data
I use error codes only
and then use a typeadapter to ignore the outer stuff
Then just use HTTP status codes
that's what I'd probably do
Guess it's time to brush up my typeadapter-foo then :simple_smile:
thanks!
i think i still use deserializers >_>
time to not
TypeAdapter / JsonReader > deserializer
yep added a card for that
I assume you want to know why? or you just trust me?
i think it bypasses something that deserializers use which is slower, i remember the docs saying type adapter was better when i implemented it but i couldn’t figure them out :smile:
typeadapter and jsonreader are streaming
i mean yes i trust you undoubtedly :smile:
even better
:smile:
maybe i’ll make it into a lesson into measuring performance
since i’m still not too good at that
probably not too bad on small objects like the example above
reddit’s api can return 25~100 objects with like 25 fields each, i haven’t really noticed any problems with using deserializers but i do have a decently high end phone
plus that happens at the tail end of a network call so it’s hard to notice

text: anyone know if it’s possible to expose a string which is added at build time, to a JNI class? I have been obfuscating an API key by including it in a native class, instead of Java which is usually decompiled first. I want to open source my app though so now I have to feed the key at build time instead of checking it into git
i have a feeling i should just roll with a different approach
encrypting/decrypting a file with the key or something like that. but hackers would just reverse engineer my encryption algorithm
Why are you even bothering? This sounds like a huge headache for no reason
<@U0546QERR>: strings in native objects are easier to extract than strings in Java classes, IMO
just assume anything you package into your APK will be visible by everyone
don’t bother trying to hide it
you cant
sorry was driving home... <@U060Q7J2Y> that's basically what i've read, but i'm not trying to outrun the bear, i'm just trying to outrun you
you cant outrun me
you’re wasting your time
it's not going to hurt anyone if someone gets my flurry key, but they can screw with my data if they want
so i'd rather they pick someone else
i mean…just cause you hide it in JNI doesn’t mean I can’t get it
lemme just open my friend charles proxy and…gg
you'll be less likely to do that if you can get it in plain text from pizza hut :wink:
i know if someone wants to screw with ME they would be able to do it
but most hackers just want to screw with _someone_
i think you’re just being paranoid
but
whatever, you do you homie :stuck_out_tongue:
i know what you mean
it's just hard to put my API keys in plain text when every article out there tells you to not do that
and i figured it's a skill i should probably learn before i need to protect something more valuable
but then i'm probably buying a web server and going that route
don’t believe everything you read :stuck_out_tongue:
I don't protect my Fabric key
I don't care what they do with that key
Regarding my server stuff, I do put everything in environment variables
putting a key in an apk == plain text
pretty easy to get it always
environmental variables are on your build machine though. you have to put them in the apk at some point
and at that point, they are free game
so how are they protected exactly? lol
they arent.
which is my point
give up
this is a message of hope. give up
so... don't code anything that involves something you need to protect. got it
my next app will be tic tac toe
no
my point is you cant
so spend your time doing other things
So just to clarify why you should not bother with the key in jni
You can take any apk and make it debuggable
Because of that it does not matter where you put the key
It will be visible at some point
You don't need a proxy or hacks, just a debugger and some knowledge
proxy is probably the easiest though
all the keys for everything come out
and the routes
and everything
Depends on your goals
`strings myapk.apk` is generally enough for unencrypted strings
Also, if you're on Windows try Fiddler as proxy. I found it to be way more capable than Charles
It's also scriptable so that is nice
Proxy alone won't help you with ssl pinning tho, then you need to hack around the apk too
And there are things like DexGuard which make all that pretty cumbersome

<@U08TSB200|sdhrumit> uploaded a file: <https://androidchat.slack.com/files/sdhrumit/F0APD5W2W/device-2015-09-16-111445.png|device-2015-09-16-111445.png> and commented: Hi I am using design support library
I have tab layout and floating action button inside coordinate layout.
I need seperate click events of floating action button inside tab's fragment 
Suppose if user click FAB from Application tab some dialog will be open and 
if user click FAB from Facebook tab some other dialog will be open.
So how to achieve this kind of functionality

initial_comment.comment:
Hi I am using design support library
I have tab layout and floating action button inside coordinate layout.
I need seperate click events of floating action button inside tab's fragment 
Suppose if user click FAB from Application tab some dialog will be open and 
if user click FAB from Facebook tab some other dialog will be open.
So how to achieve this kind of functionality

text: Just keep track of what fragment is currently active and act accordingly in your FAB lsitener

<@U07MUKUBW>: 
>Any Behavior associated with the *direct* child of the CoordinatorLayout may elect to accept the nested scroll as part of onStartNestedScroll(CoordinatorLayout, V, View, View, int).
It will only work for direct childs of the CoordinatorLayout
I learned that the hard way too
See this: <https://code.google.com/p/android/issues/detail?id=181687>
Does this mean its not possible?
What about the nestedscrollchild interface and all
well, looking at your SO question; do you add or replace into that fragment container FrameLayout?
In theory if you replace, then it should be a direct child
wait no, don’t think that is how it works, nvm
Can i get click event of FAB inside each fragment?

You’d have to route the event through the activity to the fragment with some callback I think, since attaching an OnClikcListener in each fragment won’t allow you to distinguish what fragment is displayed  anyway

I am using FragmentPagerAdapter with viewpager, offScreenPageLimit = number of tabs so if i use click event in each fragment it will override with last fragment click.
So what is the solution to achieve this?
Have the OCL in your Activity, check what fragment  is currently shown and pass the event to that fragment
<https://plus.google.com/+AndroidDevelopers/posts/SXVtgnoKcAY?linkId=17056826>
